posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
The first time I attempt to connect to a robot and uploaded code it often take my laptop grater than 2 minutes to find the rio then upload the changes. The upload itself is as fast as expected.

At one time I had a discuttion with someone that it because my laptop has connected network drives that are currently not connected and deleting these would resolve the issue, but then I would have to reconnect these when I return to the office.

Does this makes sense and is there a way to configure VSCode or the WPILib addon to only look at the USB and any other expected locations it should find the Robot?

posts.name: Joe Ross
Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
I took your recommendations to test

All are connected to the robot via USB

Test 1

disabled wifi

turned off Firewalls

rebooted laptop

upload was desirable < 30 sec

Test 2

disabled wifi

turned on Firewalls

rebooted laptop

upload was desirable < 30 sec

Test 3

Re-enabled wifi

turned on Firewalls

rebooted laptop

the upload was UN-desirable > 150 sec

Turned off wifi (No reboot) and desirable uploads returned. ( < 30 sec) I usually use USB while making presentations so I can use the internet connector for online resources during the presentation.

I may have missed the timing of the delay. Attached is a screen capture of Screenshot 2024-06-02 200631 889×309 29.5 KB the delay during the INITIALIZING step.

Screenshot 2024-06-02 200631 889×309 29.5 KB

Screenshot 2024-06-02 200631 889×309 29.5 KB

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: That’s interesting. When running with deploy, —offline is specified meaning gradle itself shouldn’t be trying to hit the network. And gradlerio won’t try until after initialization finishes. Can you run a deploy from the terminal ‘./gradlew deploy —info’ (2 dashes before info) and post the results of that? I wonder what it’s trying to hit.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
If it’s taking forever to initialize, it very well could be gradle attempting to interact with mapped but disconnected network drives. Try running with --watch-fs - if that’s the issue, that will speed it up significantly.

Gradle 7 is very slow on Windows when there are disconnected network drives opened 11:15AM - 05 Aug 21 UTC evpaassen a:bug in:virtual-file-system

Gradle 7 is very slow on Windows when there are disconnected network drives opened 11:15AM - 05 Aug 21 UTC evpaassen a:bug in:virtual-file-system

opened 11:15AM - 05 Aug 21 UTC evpaassen

opened 11:15AM - 05 Aug 21 UTC

evpaassen

a:bug in:virtual-file-system

<!--- 
Please follow the instructions below. 
We receive dozens of issues ever … y week, so to stay productive, we will close issues that don't provide enough information. 

Please open Android-related issues on the Android Issue Tracker at https://source.android.com/source/report-bugs
Please open Gradle Native-related issues at https://github.com/gradle/gradle-native/issues
-->



### Expected Behavior
When a build is completed, Gradle completes within a reasonable amount of time.

### Current Behavior
When a build is completed on a Windows 10 system and there are disconnected network drives (smb shares mounted to a drive letter), Gradle takes 30s to 60s extra to complete, after it has printed 'BUILD SUCCEEDED'. The progress indicator just shows 'Idle' all this time.

**Gradle 6.9 didn't have the problem. It was only introduced in 7.0.**

When running `./gradlew build --debug`, it looks like the additional time is spent acquiring and releasing locks on network shares that are disconnected (because these are only reachable over VPN, which is disconnected most of the time).

*(I redacted usernames and network share paths in the log output.)*

When I connect the VPNs, so both network shares are available, Gradle terminates almost instantly after completing the build.

### Context
Every single build in every project takes an additional amount of time, often much more than the time actually needed to build the project in the first place.

### Steps to Reproduce 
You can probably reproduce this issue by:
1. [mapping a network drive](https://www.dummies.com/computers/pcs/mapping-a-network-drive-on-your-windows-10-pc/) on Windows 10
2. disconnecting it (for example by disconnecting the VPN it connects through)
3. running `./gradlew build` on any simple Gradle project, for example a Gradle project generated through https://start.spring.io/.
4. watching the build succeed, but the process not terminating for some time.

### Your Environment

```
$ ./gradlew --version

------------------------------------------------------------

OS:           Windows 10 10.0 amd64
```

### Expected Behavior
When a build is completed, Gradle completes within a reasonable amount of time.

### Current Behavior
When a build is completed on a Windows 10 system and there are disconnected network drives (smb shares mounted to a drive letter), Gradle takes 30s to 60s extra to complete, after it has printed 'BUILD SUCCEEDED'. The progress indicator just shows 'Idle' all this time.

**Gradle 6.9 didn't have the problem. It was only introduced in 7.0.**

When running `./gradlew build --debug`, it looks like the additional time is spent acquiring and releasing locks on network shares that are disconnected (because these are only reachable over VPN, which is disconnected most of the time).

*(I redacted usernames and network share paths in the log output.)*

When I connect the VPNs, so both network shares are available, Gradle terminates almost instantly after completing the build.

### Context
Every single build in every project takes an additional amount of time, often much more than the time actually needed to build the project in the first place.

### Steps to Reproduce 
You can probably reproduce this issue by:
1. [mapping a network drive](https://www.dummies.com/computers/pcs/mapping-a-network-drive-on-your-windows-10-pc/) on Windows 10
2. disconnecting it (for example by disconnecting the VPN it connects through)
3. running `./gradlew build` on any simple Gradle project, for example a Gradle project generated through https://start.spring.io/.
4. watching the build succeed, but the process not terminating for some time.

### Your Environment

```
$ ./gradlew --version

------------------------------------------------------------
Gradle 7.1.1
------------------------------------------------------------

Build time:   2021-07-02 12:16:43 UTC
Revision:     774525a055494e0ece39f522ac7ad17498ce032c

Ant:          Apache Ant(TM) version 1.10.9 compiled on September 27 2020
JVM:          11.0.7 (AdoptOpenJDK 11.0.7+10)
OS:           Windows 10 10.0 amd64
```

link_counts.title: Gradle 7 is very slow on Windows when there are disconnected network drives · Issue #17955 · gradle/gradle · GitHub

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked: Thanks this currently fits the issue I’m seeing. I will try the suggested resolution [ disable file system watching entirely using org.gradle.vfs.watch=false in gradle.properties ] tonight along with @Thad_House request.

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
Can confirm adding the --no-watch-fs to the build help a ton. Now at 6 sec build deploy. What I did was got to File > Preferences > Settings > User > Extensions > WPILib configuration > Additional Gradle Argumets and added the --no-watch-fs image 1211×561 51.3 KB

image 1211×561 51.3 KB

image 1211×561 51.3 KB

Try cleaning your gradle build cache, you can do this by:

in the terminal (be sure that the working directory is where your robot code is located)

On Windows gradle cache is located at:

After deleting the cache, the first build should take a long time, but subsequent builds should be faster.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: I’ve had similar issues and also have disconnected mapped drives, I have to give this a try. This might be something helpful to add to wpilib docs.
